intro: Cacalia punctulata, commonly known as the spotted bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in open woodlands and meadows, preferring well-drained soils. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a hairy texture, while its stems are upright and branching. Cacalia punctulata is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological role in supporting pollinators.
